thread.title: Plainfield South football now waits for playoff fate
thread.title_full: Plainfield South football now waits for playoff fate

title: Plainfield South football now waits for playoff fate
text:
Plainfield South football now waits for playoff fate   12:47 a.m. CDT Caption (Steven Buyansky for Shaw Media) Plainfield South running back Jake Maher runs into the Oswego line Friday. By KRISTIN SHARP - ksharp@shawmedia.com 
OSWEGO â€“ Now, the waiting game begins for the Plainfield South football players and coaches. Related Links Lockport football spoils Joliet West's playoff hopes 
The Cougars capped the regular season with a 28-7 loss at Oswego on Friday night and now hope a 5-4 record with 43 playoff points is enough to give Plainfield South one of 32 spots when the Class 8A playoff field is announced Saturday night. 
"I think we've got a better than average chance to get in, but we're going to find out," Plainfield South head coach Ken Bublitz said. "I just hope for these kids' sake because they played their tails off. Now we'll just have to see." 
Plainfield South accepted the opening kickoff, but fumbled on its first play from scrimmage to set the tone for the night. 
Oswego had two unanswered touchdowns to go up 14-0 early in the second quarter. 
The Cougars put together a 13-play drive and came up big on a fourth-and-12 situation when quarterback Jackson Howarth found Austin Deal for a 21-yard gain to the Oswego 12. Two plays later, Howarth threw a 14-yard touchdown pass to Jake Portz and Enrique Carbajal's extra point was good for a 14-7 score. 
Oswego responded, however, and went up to a 21-7 lead with 1:45 to play in the third quarter. Midway through the fourth the Panthers added one final score. 
With the help of a Minooka win over Plainfield North, Oswego wins its fifth consecutive Southwest Prairie Conference championship with a 6-1 record, while Plainfield South and Plainfield North tie for second at 5-2.
